indicated by the singleness of the aperture through which it passes. In the
specimen figured in Plate VII Fig 8 we see this to be the case only
with the <u>three</u> zones nearest the centre; in that represented in
Plate V Fig 2 the canal is single in the <u>five</u> inner zones; whilst
in that represented in Plate VII Fig.4, the canal is single for the
first twenty-three zones. Whenever the annulus canal is single,
the upper and lower superficial cells also become continuous
and form a series of columnar cells in every respect similar to
those of the simple type. (compare Plate II Fig. 4 with the
portion <u>a-b</u> of Plate VII Fig 4) If, then, the growth of either
of these disks had been checked within the first zone<s>,</s> in which
its annular canal becomes double, it would have been accounted
as belonging to the simpler type; and the wide variation which
here shows itself, in regard to the distance from the nucleus<s>,</s> at
which the more complex type begins to be assumed, sufficiently
explains the fact already noticed (§22), that although the disks
of this 'simple' type are for the most part of minute size, yet that the
diameter of many of them exceeds that of the smaller disks of
the complex type.
